sen.j: 分部 光命（わけべ みつなが、正徳 (日本)4年1月8日 (旧暦)（1714年2月22日）- 天明3年11月22日 (旧暦)（1783年12月15日））は、近江国大溝藩の第6代藩主。
sen.e: Mitsunaga WAKEBE (February 22, 1714 - December 15, 1783) was the 6th lord of the Omizo Domain, Omi Province.
Mitsunaga WAKEBE (February 22, 1714 - December 15, 1783) was the 6th lord of the Omizo Domain, Omi Province.
Mitsunaga WAKEBE (February 22, 1714 - December 15, 1783) was the 6th lord of the Omizo Domain, Omi Province.
He was the 7th head of the Wakebe family.
He was the 7th head of the Wakebe family.
He was the 7th head of the Wakebe family.

sen.j: 第5代藩主・分部光忠の長男。
sen.e: He was the first son of Mitsutada WAKEBE, the 5th lord of the domain.
He was the first son of Mitsutada WAKEBE, the 5th lord of the domain.
He was the first son of Mitsutada WAKEBE, the 5th lord of the domain.
His mother was from the Tani clan.
His mother was from the Tani clan.
His mother was from the Tani clan.
His lawful wife was from the Imamura clan.
His lawful wife was from the Imamura clan.
His lawful wife was from the Imamura clan.

sen.j: 子に分部光庸（長男）、三淵澄鮮（次男）、三淵澄盈（三男）、施薬院宗顕（四男）、中條康永（五男）、分部命誠（六男）、娘（越前松平堅房正室）、娘（角倉玄寿室）、娘（長岡栄之室）、娘（恒川忠栄室）。
sen.e: He had children including Mitsutsune WAKEBE (the first son), Chosen (澄鮮) MITSUBUCHI (the second son), Choei (澄盈) MITSUBUCHI (the third son), Seyakuin Soken (施薬院宗顕) (the fourth son), Yoshinaga CHUJO (the fifth son), Nagaaki (命誠) WAKEBE (the sixth), a daughter (lawful wife of Katafusa MATSUDAIRA of Echizen), a daughter (wife of Genju (玄寿) KADOKURA), a daughter (wife of Hideyuki (栄之) NAGAOKA), and a daughter (wife of Tadahide (忠栄) TSUNEKAWA).
sen.cmt: 分部光庸（わけべみつつね）<http://roadsite.road.jp/history/daimyo/wakebe/wakebe.html>「三淵澄鮮」「三淵澄盈」「施薬院宗顕」「分部命誠」「角倉玄寿」「長岡栄之」「恒川忠栄」の読み不明中條康永(ちゅうじょうやすなが)<http://www4.airnet.ne.jp/soutai/01_soutai/04-2_ti/08-3_yu/tyujou_yasunaga/tyujou_yasunaga.html>越前松平堅房（まつだいら かたふさ）<http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%BE%E5%B9%B3%E5%A0%85%E6%88%BF>
sen.e: He had children including Mitsutsune WAKEBE (the first son), Chosen (澄鮮) MITSUBUCHI (the second son), Choei (澄盈) MITSUBUCHI (the third son), Seyakuin Soken (施薬院宗顕) (the fourth son), Yoshinaga CHUJO (the fifth son), Nagaaki (命誠) WAKEBE (the sixth), a daughter (lawful wife of Katafusa MATSUDAIRA of Echizen), a daughter (wife of Genju (玄寿) KADOKURA), a daughter (wife of Hideyuki (栄之) NAGAOKA), and a daughter (wife of Tadahide (忠栄) TSUNEKAWA).

He had children including Mitsutsune WAKEBE (the first son), Chosen (澄鮮) MITSUBUCHI (the second son), Choei (澄盈) MITSUBUCHI (the third son), Seyakuin Soken (施薬院宗顕) (the fourth son), Yoshinaga CHUJO (the fifth son), Nagaaki (命誠) WAKEBE (the sixth), a daughter (lawful wife of Katafusa MATSUDAIRA of Echizen), a daughter (wife of Genju (玄寿) KADOKURA), a daughter (wife of Hideyuki (栄之) NAGAOKA), and a daughter (wife of Tadahide (忠栄) TSUNEKAWA).

sen.j: 官位は従五位下、和泉国守、若狭国守。
sen.e: His court rank was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and his official posts were Izumi no kuni no kami (governor of Izumi Province) and Wakasa no kuni no kami (governor of Wakasa Province).
His court rank was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and his official posts were Izumi no kuni no kami (governor of Izumi Province) and Wakasa no kuni no kami (governor of Wakasa Province).
His court rank was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and his official posts were Izumi no kuni no kami (governor of Izumi Province) and Wakasa no kuni no kami (governor of Wakasa Province).
He was born on January 8, 1714.
He was born on January 8, 1714.
He was born on February 22, 1714.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変更して最初の日付と合わせました。

sen.e: His childhood name was Kumanosuke.
His childhood name was Kumanosuke.
His childhood name was Kumanosuke.

sen.j: 享保16年（1731年）、父の死により後を継ぐ。
sen.e: In 1731, he succeeded his father who died.
In 1731, he succeeded his father who died.
In 1731, he succeeded his father who died.

sen.j: 宝暦4年（1754年）9月7日、長男の光庸に家督を譲って隠居し、宝暦10年（1760年）には病気療養を理由に摂津国有馬温泉にて保養した。
sen.e: On September 7, 1754, he handed over the family headship to the first son of him Mitsutsune for retirement and then went to the Arima-onsen Hotspring in Settsu Province to recuperate in 1760.
On September 7, 1754, he handed over the family headship to the first son of him Mitsutsune for retirement and then went to the Arima-onsen Hotspring in Settsu Province to recuperate in 1760.
On October 22, 1754, he handed over the family headship to the first son of him Mitsutsune for retirement and then went to the Arima-onsen Hotspring in Settsu Province to recuperate in 1760.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変更しました。

sen.j: 明和6年（1769年）に剃髪して風斎と号し、天明3年（1783年）11月22日（または11月17日とも）に70歳で死去した。
sen.e: He became a monk with the name of (風斎) Fusai in 1769 and then died at the age of 70 on November 22 (or November 17), 1783.
He became a monk with the name of (風斎) Fusai in 1769 and then died at the age of 70 on November 22 (or November 17), 1783.
He became a monk with the name of (風斎) Fusai in 1769 and then died at the age of 70 on December 15 (or December 10), 1783.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変更して最初の日付と合わせました。

sen.j: 法号：直心院殿円空慶算大居士。
sen.e: His hogo (posthumous Buddhist name) was Chokushininden Enku Keisan Daikoji (直心院殿円空慶算大居士).
sen.cmt: 直心院殿円空慶算大居士の読み不明
sen.e: His hogo (posthumous Buddhist name) was Chokushininden Enku Keisan Daikoji (直心院殿円空慶算大居士).
His hogo (posthumous Buddhist name) was Chokushininden Enku Keisan Daikoji (直心院殿円空慶算大居士).

sen.j: 墓所：滋賀県高島市の円光寺。
sen.e: Graveyard: The Enko-ji Temple, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture.
Graveyard: The Enko-ji Temple, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture.
Graveyard: The Enko-ji Temple, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture.
